sections.title: About Dialectical Thinking
sections.content: Dialectical Thinking helps you hold two truths at the same time instead of seeing things in all-or-nothing terms. It teaches you to replace "but" with "and," allowing conflicting experiences to coexist. For example: "I'm proud of myself, and I can keep growing." This shift reduces self-criticism and creates room for both acceptance and improvement.

sections.title: Example
sections.content: Sarah often thought, "I'm proud of myself, but I could have done better," which made her feel deflated. With Dialectical Thinking, she shifted to "I'm proud of myself, and I can keep growing." This simple change let her feel both satisfied with her efforts and motivated to improve at the same time.

sections.title: Remember
sections.content: Dialectical Thinking isn't about agreeing with everything or eliminating difficult emotions. It's making space for complexity and navigating life with more flexibility and understanding.
